ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: It would be nice to have a class trip to GE to put things into perspective. Overall, Great Class! ThanksKris.

This class was supposed to be about management and leadership, but it was only about corporate hierarchy. I think that there are many more aspects to leadership and management that could have been covered but were not.

This was one of my two "most relevant to my future"/"best use of my time" courses this semester. I didn't necessarily expect that an evening 1 credit course in Management would be so useful to me, but the lecturer, Kris Morico, was that good.Not only did she share really valuable insights into how corporations work, especially GE, but she gave a lot of her views from being on the management side, things that you can only know from a decade (or more? Sorry Kris!) of experience. It was also useful for women studying the sciences to see an FES alum who has really succeeded in engineering, and in corporate industry, not academia. The course should have been publicized better though.This course, more than any other resource thus far at FES made me realize the value of an FES degree as well as the FES alumni connections. Thanks for offering it and arranging for an outside speaker to come in every week.
It was great.
The Q&A session with the instructor's partner, who works in HR.
The professor was very knowledgable about EHandS and the corporate world. She spoke frankly and intelligently and is overall a lovely and nice person.
The readings are brief and very illustrative. They're definitively worth the time.
Morico's real world experience, she was also very passionate and compelling. She told stories well and related them to our current goals well.

I feel very honored to have had such close access to someone with an amazing breadth of leadership experience like Kris. She was absolutely the best part of the course, and her own perspective and life experiences proved to be invaluable educational tools.

Kris Morico--she has a wide wealth of experience in industry, and it was so helpful to hear how she moved up the ladder to her current position. Also, the guest lecturer from human resources (and subsequent Q&A) was uniquely helpful. My notes from what she said Human Resources looks for will be pulled out in exactly one year when I am interviewing for a job!

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: There is need for a real course in management at F&ES, and this course just skimmed over key terms and ideas, with very little depth on anything useful.
Exploring other aspects of leadership and management applicable to students outside of EHandS.
I think the class should be redesigned. It lacks the innovative green thinking that one would expect.

Generic powerpoints provided a good foundation for the class, but were also a bit painful to sit through. I also think we should have spent a little more time discussing the reading material (which would force student to actually read them).

I enjoyed the last exercise we did, in exploring the CSR and global sustainability activities companies were doing. It would be a great idea to build this into the curriculum  maybe in the future each student could give a 10-15 minute presentation on a company, and this could take place over the duration of the course. It would help expose the class to a breadth of companies and their management structures.
The slides were pretty bad--very generic

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Great-Mariana did a great job scheduling things (and also getting pizza and thai food). Both Mariana and Kris did a great job, and we really appreciated that they brought in dinner food a couple times, that was just really considerate and set a good tone for the course.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This is a VERY brief introduction to business stuff. If you know nothing about the subject, take it. Otherwise, don't.
Have a current high-level employee come and speak about working in the private sector.

I do not anticipate that I will ever be able to take a cross-listed class at SOM, so this class fills in the gap nicely by providing exposure to how management and leadership work in the private sector without requiring a full 3-credit commitment. It is important to have this option since all FES students need to be exposed to these issues but many may not ever have the opportunity to build it into their schedule other than a 1-credit course option.

PSCs help MEMs and MEScs to gain professional skills that they wouldn't otherwise have access to in typical courses. (Ok, I take primarily science courses at FES, so for me, these PSCs are the best way to prepare for a future in a professional (ie, non-academic) setting)I enjoy PSCs because it is information I would not otherwise have access to.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To gain an insiders perspective of EHS in a corporate role.
I wanted to compare this course to the leadership material that Susan Clark teaches. I think what Susan teaches is must more applicable to my education.
I was expecting to see some green managerial approaches.
I'm interested in GE and understanding professional skills&management in the private sector.

I took the course because I am interested in management, and had heard good things about Kris Morico from a classmate. PSCs are some of the best offerings at FES, both for MEMs and MEScs, I feel really lucky to have been able to take this course and learn from an industry leader. It was especially inspiring that she is an FES grad.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
No
No, it did not.
Not exactly. It was all about PPT slides and random tips. Anyways, it's a 1 credit class.
Yes.

Yes. I learned a lot about a subject matter that I had very little prior exposure to. What I wound up gaining the most from this course was an appreciation for my previous managers and all the work and thought they put into creating an environment that I could work effectively within. It is very hard, and I can only hope that I can someday perform as gracefully as they did in a workplace setting.
Absolutely. Exceeded.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
No
No
Yes.

I expected to get an introduction to management from an environmental perspective, and to learn about how expectations and styles of leadership might differ for environmental professionals compared to professionals working on other issues.

Yes, learned about management, learned more from Kris's stories from the workplace--how to approach negotiations, how to deal with problems in the workplace professionally, with personnel conflicts, etc. I feel better prepared to interact in a professional job after this course, and jotted down a lot of notes in the margins of Kris's tips on how she solved a problem at work, stuff that wasn't in the slides, but that I thought was more valuable.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The project was minor and required very little group work.
It was more helpful and faster.
You always learn by working as a team. In this case, I think it's all about speed working.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Have an open mind.
Take a course at SOM
Be advised that it only examines one small form of management and no leadership.
Take the class only if you don't know anything about businesses and organizations.
Go in open minded and ready to discuss and ask questions.

Realize that the real benefit of this course is the chance to tap into the instructors personal knowledge and experiences. To this end  come to class with questions and do not be afraid to ask them! The answers are usually very insightful.
With PSCs the person teaching the course is often more important than the course description--google the person's name and figure out if it could be useful to you.
